Fig. 1 TPR spectra of the series of 10% Ni–Fe/SiO2 catalysts: (a) 0Ni10.0Fe/SiO2, (b) 2.5Ni7.5Fe/SiO2, (c) 5.0Ni5.0Fe/SiO2, (d) 7.5Ni2.5Fe/SiO2 and (e) 10.0Ni0Fe/SiO2. Fig. 2 TPR spectra of the series of 10% Ni–Fe/Al2O3 catalysts: (a) 0Ni10.0Fe/Al2O3, (b) 2.5Ni7.5Fe/Al2O3, (c) 5.0Ni5.0Fe/Al2O3, (d) 7.5Ni2.5Fe/Al2O3 and (e) 10.0Ni0Fe/Al2O3. Fig. 3 TPR spectra of the series of 30% Ni–Fe/Al2O3 catalysts: (a) 0Ni30.0Fe/Al2O3, (b) 7.5Ni22.5Fe/Al2O3, (c) 15.0Ni15.0Fe/Al2O3, (d) 22.5Ni7.5Fe/Al2O3 and (e) 30.0Ni0Fe/Al2O3. Fig. 4 XRD patterns of SiO2 and the series of 10% Ni–Fe/SiO2 catalysts, reduced with H2 at 773K for 4h: (a) SiO2, (b) 0Ni10.0Fe/SiO2, (c) 2.5Ni7.5Fe/SiO2, (d) 5.0Ni5.0Fe/SiO2, (e) 7.5Ni2.5Fe/SiO2 and (f) 10.0Ni0Fe/SiO2. Fig. 5 XRD patterns of Al2O3 and the series of 30% Ni–Fe/Al2O3 catalysts, reduced with H2 at 773K for 4h: (a) Al2O3, (b) 0Ni30.0Fe/Al2O3, (c) 7.5Ni22.5Fe/Al2O3, (d) 15.0Ni15.0Fe/Al2O3, (e) 22.5Ni7.5Fe/Al2O3 and (f) 30.0Ni0Fe/Al2O3. Fig. 6 CO2 conversion and CH4 yield for the series of 10% Ni–Fe/SiO2 catalysts at 523K. Fig. 7 CO2 conversion and CH4 yield for the series of 10% and 30% Ni–Fe/Al2O3 catalysts at 523K. Graphical abstract Nickel (Ni), iron (Fe) and three series of Ni–Fe bimetallic catalysts supported on alumina and silica were tested for the CO2 hydrogenation reaction at 448–548K. The supported Ni–Fe catalysts containing 75wt.% of the total metal loading as Ni and 25wt.% as Fe showed a significantly better CO2 conversion and higher methane (CH4) yield compared to the Ni and Fe supported catalysts. Furthermore, the enhancements of conversion and yield were higher for the alumina supported catalysts than for the silica supported catalysts. The enhancements appear to be independent of total metal loading. It appears that the enhancements of conversion and yield were due to the formation of a suitable Ni–Fe alloy, and/or increase in the number of metal sites, and/or the availability of adsorbed CO2 species. Keywords Carbon dioxide hydrogenation Nickel Iron Bimetallic catalyst 1 Introduction Nickel–iron, Ni–Fe, based catalysts are used for several reactions, such as, tar removal in biomass steam gasification [1], partial oxidation of CH4 [2–4], combined hydrogenation of carbon oxides [5,6], CH4 decomposition at moderate temperatures [7], hydrodechlorination of trichloroethylene to hydrocarbons [8] and hydrodeoxygenation of oxygenates (n-butanonide, butyric acid and butanone) [9]. In these catalysts it appears that the qualities of Ni and Fe are combined to enhance the activity and selectivity. In many of these Ni–Fe based catalysts the Ni and Fe ratio has an effect on the catalytic activity and selectivity. Furthermore, the support may play an important role, for example, by enhancing the specific surface area of the active metal and/or affecting the activity and selectivity of the catalysts [10–12]. The enhancement in activity for the Ni–Fe based catalysts has been attributed to various factors, including the formation of alloys, change in reducibility, stabilization of the Ni phase, control of migration of Ni from the surface to the bulk and homogeneous distribution of the catalyst. In the present work Ni, Fe and three series of supported Ni–Fe catalysts were synthesized to determine the effect of (i) Ni to Fe ratio, (ii) support (silica or alumina) and (iii) total metal loading on the catalytic activity. To assist in the understanding of the supported Ni–Fe catalysts the samples were characterized and tested for the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. Carbon dioxide hydrogenation was chosen as a probe reaction since previous studies reveal that supported Ni catalysts were more active and selective compared to Fe, which was less active and prone to carbon deposition [13,14]. Thus, it was expected that changes in activity with Ni:Fe ratio, support and total metal loading can be readily detected and compared. Diffuse reflectance infrared (DRIFT) spectroscopy was also employed to facilitate the understanding of the catalyst during reaction conditions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis Nickel, Fe and Ni–Fe supported on alumina and silica catalysts were synthesized using the incipient wetness impregnation method. A total metal loading of 10wt.% was supported on silica, and a total metal loadings of 10 and 30wt.% were supported on alumina. The supported catalysts with a total metal loading of 10% wt. were prepared by single impregnation and those supported catalysts containing a total metal loading of 30% were prepared by double impregnation method. The Ni precursor was nickel (II) nitrate hexahydrate (Sigma–Aldrich) and the Fe precursor was iron (III) nitrate nonahydrate (Sigma–Aldrich). Initially, the silica (AEROSIL-200) and alumina (Sasol) supports were pretreated with incipient wetness volumes of water using previously published procedures [15]. This pretreated support was then mixed with required amounts of an aqueous solution of the corresponding nitrates. The mixture was dried for 8h at room temperature and calcined at various temperatures from 373 to 773K and finally at 773K for 6h. In the double impregnation method the catalyst calcined at 773K and containing 15% of total metal was used for the second impregnation of the precursor solution. After second impregnation the same drying and calcination temperature sequence was used. To obtain the active form, the calcined catalysts were reduced under conditions mentioned below. The catalysts were referred to as xNiyFe/Support, where x was the amount of Ni metal taken in the precursor solution, y was the amount of Fe metal taken in the precursor solution, and Support refers to alumina (Al2O3) or silica (SiO2). 2.2 Catalyst characterization The surface areas of the samples were obtained by the BET method using N2 adsorption data at 77K. The instrument used for surface area measurements was QuantaChrome Autosorb 1C [16]. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the oxidized and reduced samples were obtained on a PANalytical X’Pert PRO Diffractometer using Ni filtered Kα radiation from a Cu target (λ =1.541841Å) [17]. A sweep of 3°min−1 and time constant of 3.0s was maintained. The International Center for Diffraction Data (ICDD) library was used for phase identification. The crystallite size values for the most prominent peak of Ni or Ni–Fe alloy or Fe of the metal supported reduced catalysts were determined by the X’Pert High Score Plus software available with the above instrument. Calcined catalysts were studied in a UV–vis–NIR spectrophotometer (Cary 5000) equipped with a diffuse reflectance accessory (Harrick Scientific). All spectra were collected under ambient condition using BaSO4 as the reference. The temperature programmed reduction using H2 (H2-TPR) studies of all catalysts were achieved using an AMI-200 setup. The results were obtained in the temperature range of 323–1223K using about 50mg of the sample. The amount of chemisorbed H2 was determined from temperature programmed desorption of H2 (H2-TPD) using the same AMI-200 setup. About 220mg of the calcined catalyst was reduced in the U-tube of the AMI-200 setup at 773 for 4h with H2 and then cooled to 313K in the same environment. The catalyst was held at 313K in argon flow to remove weakly bound physisorbed hydrogen and then the temperature was increased at a ramp rate of 10K/min to 773K. The temperature of catalyst was maintained at 773K for about 0.5h under flowing argon. The H2-TPD profile was integrated and the number of moles of desorbed H2 was determined by using pulse calibration of H2 in Ar. 2.3 Reaction setup The CO2 hydrogenation reaction was performed in a down flow tubular quartz reactor operating at atmospheric pressure. For reaction studies, 150mg of the calcined catalyst was reduced at 773K for 4h with H2 flowing at a rate of 20ml/min. The choice of reduction temperature was based on a previous study dealing with CO hydrogenation reaction [18]. After reduction, the reactor was cooled to room temperature in a nitrogen stream. Immediately after cooling, premixed reactant gases containing 4% (v/v) CO2 in H2 with a total flow rate of 80ml/min was passed through the reactor. The CO2 hydrogenation reaction was carried out at temperatures ranging from 448 to 548K. At each specific reaction temperature about 2h was given for achieving steady state. After achieving steady state gas samples were collected and analyzed by a gas chromatograph (Nucon 5765). The gas chromatograph was equipped with a carbosphere column, a methanizer and a flame ionization detector. 2.4 In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) studies In situ DRIFT studies were employed to investigate the different species formed on the different samples during the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. The DRIFT spectra of the samples were obtained using a BRUKER TENSOR 27 FTIR spectrometer containing a diffuse reflectance accessory (HARRICK Praying Mantis, DRP-BR4) and a high temperature reaction chamber (HARRICK HVC-DRP-2). The reaction chamber was equipped with ZnSe windows. The reactant stream contained a molar ratio of CO2:H2 =1:9 with a total flow rate of 50ml/min. The reaction temperature was 523K. Prior to conducting the reaction and collecting the spectra the catalysts were reduced at 823K for 4h in the same reaction cell. The thermocouple present in the high temperature reaction chamber is known to have a temperature difference with the surface of the catalyst bed [19]. For this reason the reduction temperature was kept at the highest temperature achievable by the high temperature reaction cell. All the spectra were recorded against a KBr background at a resolution of 4cm−1 using 128 scans. The exit gas was also simultaneously analyzed in the gas chromatograph mentioned above. 3 Result and discussion The surface area values of the support and the metal supported catalysts containing 10 and 30wt.% total metal loading were determined and tabulated, as in Table 1 . Also tabulated in Table 1 are the percentage degree of reduction, crystallite size and amount of H2 desorbed, which are discussed below. Analysis of Table 1 revealed that the addition of 10wt.% metal to the SiO2 and Al2O3 supports decreased the surface area of the catalyst to values ranging from 153 to 175m2/g. Addition of 30wt.% metal to the Al2O3 support revealed a further decrease in surface area of the catalyst to values ranging from 106 to 127m2/g. Changing the Ni:Fe ratio for these two total metal loadings did not show any specific trend in the changes in surface area values. Similar observations were made previously for Ni–Fe catalysts supported on Al2O3 and MgAl2O4 [18]. X-ray diffraction patterns were obtained for the supports, and the calcined and reduced supported catalysts. The XRD patterns of the calcined and reduced Al2O3 supported Ni, Fe and Ni–Fe catalysts containing 10wt.% of total metal were dominated by the support features and are not shown for brevity. The XRD patterns of the calcined SiO2 supported catalysts containing 10wt.% total metal and the Al2O3 supported catalysts containing 30wt.% total metal are shown in Figs. S1 and S2 (in Supplementary information). The XRD patterns revealed the presence of nickel oxide, iron oxides and the support phase. The XRD patterns of calcined 10.0Ni0Fe/SiO2 revealed the presence of NiO, and calcined 0Ni10.0Fe/SiO2 revealed the presence of Fe2O3. Substituting 25% of the Fe with Ni revealed new peaks at 35.71° and 62.89° due to the presence of Fe3O4 in addition to the peaks associated with NiO [20]. By increasing the substitution amount of Fe with Ni resulted in the growth of the NiO peaks and a decrease in the intensity of the Fe3O4 peaks. Interestingly, Fe2O3 was not observed in the SiO2 supported catalysts containing both Ni and Fe. The XRD patterns of the calcined 30.0Ni0Fe/Al2O3 and 0Ni30.0Fe/Al2O3 samples also revealed the presence of NiO and Fe2O3, respectively. Substituting 25% of the Fe with Ni resulted in a decrease in the Fe2O3 peaks and the appearance of peaks due to Fe3O4. Further substitution of Fe with Ni revealed the presence of Fe3O4 and small peaks due to trace amounts of NiO; peaks due to Fe2O3 were not observed. Thus, it appears that the presence of NiO on SiO2 and Al2O3 supported catalysts containing both Ni and Fe oxides facilitate the formation of Fe3O4. UV–vis studies were undertaken due to the difficulty in obtaining the XRD patterns for the calcined Al2O3 supported catalysts containing 10wt.% total metal. The UV–vis spectra were collected under ambient conditions for the supports and the series of calcined and reduced supported catalysts in the 350–800nm region. Similar to the observations from the XRD patterns above the UV–vis spectra of the calcined supported catalysts revealed the presence of NiO, Fe2O3 and Fe3O4. Only the spectra of the calcined Al2O3 supported catalysts containing 10wt.% total metal are shown in Fig. S3 (in Supplementary information). For the 10.0Ni0Fe/SiO2, 10.0Ni0Fe/Al2O3 and 30.0Ni0Fe/Al2O3 samples absorption bands were observed at 380, 420 and 720nm. These bands were assigned to octahedral NiO [21,22]. For the 0Ni10.0Fe/SiO2, 0Ni10.0Fe/Al2O3 and 0Ni30.0Fe/Al2O3 samples an absorption band was observed at 530nm, which has been assigned to Fe2O3 [23,24]. Substituting 25% of Fe with Ni resulted in a decrease in intensity of the due to Fe2O3 and the growth of a band at 750nm, which has been assigned to Fe3O4 [25]. The band at 750nm decreased when more than 25% Fe was substituted with Ni. In the SiO2 and Al2O3 supported samples containing both Ni and Fe oxides the Fe3O4 band was clearly observed, which was consistent with the XRD studies. Thus, the UV–vis and XRD characterization of the calcined supported samples revealed varying amounts of NiO, Fe2O3 and Fe3O4 on the SiO2 and Al2O3 supports, with Fe3O4 preferentially being formed when Ni and Fe oxides was simultaneously present. The H2-TPR profiles were collected for the series of calcined supported catalysts. The H2-TPR profiles of the series of SiO2 supported samples containing 10% total metal loading and the series of Al2O3 supported samples containing 10% and 30% total metal loading are shown in Figs. 1–3 . In Fig. 1, the H2-TPR profiles of the series of SiO2 supported samples containing 10% total metal are shown. The reduction profile of 0Ni10.0Fe/SiO2 revealed three distinct peaks at 660, 778 and 945K. A small shoulder was also observed at 685K. In contrast, 10.0Ni0Fe/SiO2 revealed a single reduction peak at 668K suggesting that Ni oxide is easier to reduce and conversion to the metal involves a single reduction step. For the SiO2 supported catalyst containing Ni and Fe the reduction peak at 945K due to Fe oxide was not observed. For the 2.5Ni7.5Fe/SiO2 sample, the first two reduction peaks of Fe oxide appear to be shifted to lower temperatures. An additional peak at 681K was also observed, which may be due to the reduction of Ni oxide species. The reduction profile of 5.0Ni5.0Fe/SiO2 revealed two peaks at 641 and 749K. For the 7.5Ni2.5Fe/SiO2 catalyst a single reduction peak at 648K was observed, which was more intense and at a lower temperature compared to the 10.0Ni0Fe/SiO2 catalyst. The TPR profiles of the series of the Al2O3 supported samples containing 10% total metal are shown in Fig. 2. The reduction profile of 0Ni10.0Fe/Al2O3 revealed three distinct peaks at 699, 795 and 1135K. These three peaks were shifted to higher temperatures when compared with the corresponding SiO2 supported sample. The relative peak intensities were also different. For the 10.0Ni0Fe/Al2O3 sample, three distinct peaks at 706, 810 and 1048K were observed in contrast to the single peak at 668K observed for the corresponding 10.0Ni0Fe/SiO2 sample. Since the UV–vis spectra of these two samples indicate that NiO is initially present the H2-TPR profiles suggest that the reduction steps of NiO depends on the specific interaction of the NiO phase with the support. Previous studies suggest that some of these steps may involve the support [26]. Furthermore, previous studies reveal that the interaction of Ni with SiO2 and Al2O3 are different [27]. Substituting 25% of Fe with Ni, as in the 2.5Ni7.5Fe/Al2O3 catalyst, two peaks at 680 and 849K were observed. The reduction profile of 5.0Ni5.0Fe/Al2O3 revealed two peaks at 657 and 780K. A small shoulder at 1037K was also detected. The reduction profile of 7.5Ni2.5Fe/Al2O3 revealed two peaks at 748 and 1040K, and a small shoulder at 650K. Thus, the support and presence of another reducible metal oxide plays a role in the reduction of the supported catalysts containing Ni and/or Fe. In Fig. 3, the TPR profile of the series of Al2O3 supported catalyst containing 30% total metal is shown. The reduction profiles were similar to the series of Al2O3 supported catalyst containing 10% total metal shown in Fig. 2. Furthermore, the peaks were more distinct and shifted. Comparing the reduction profile of the series of Al2O3 supported catalysts containing 10% and 30% total metal (Figs. 2 and 3) suggest that the reduction of the supported Ni oxide phase occurs at a lower temperature for the 30.0Ni0Fe/Al2O3 relative to the 10.0Ni0Fe/Al2O3 catalyst; and reduction of the Fe oxide phase occurs at a higher temperature for the 0Ni30Fe/Al2O3 relative to the 0Ni10.0Fe/Al2O3 catalyst. The reduction profiles of the Al2O3 supported catalysts containing 30% of Ni and Fe possesses peaks similar to the 10% counterparts with the individual peaks shifted to lower temperature. Thus, the reduction profiles of supported catalyst containing Ni and/or Fe were affected by the support, the presence of a second reducible metal oxide, and total metal loading. The degree of reduction for the supported samples were also determined and tabulated, as in Table 1. The calculation procedure for determining the degree of reduction during TPR was similar to those previously used [28]. Table 1 revealed that the degree of reduction was: (i) higher for the SiO2 supported samples compared to the Al2O3 supported samples, and (ii) higher for the supported Ni samples compared to the supported Fe samples. Furthermore, the degree of reduction was more for those samples possessing Ni as the major component. The H2-TPR profiles for Al2O3 supported Ni, Fe and Ni–Fe catalysts have been studied previously [20,29]. However, detailed analyses of the effect of total metal loading, composition and support were not considered in that study. Based on the H2-TPR profiles a reduction temperature of 773K would appear to be sufficient to reduce the Ni oxide and majority of the Fe oxide phases for the SiO2 supported catalysts. For the Al2O3 supported catalysts, however, the situation is different due to the more involved reduction profiles of the supported Ni and Fe oxides. It is possible that the Al2O3 supported Ni and Fe oxides are not completely reduced at 773K. The XRD patterns of the reduced SiO2 supported catalysts containing 10wt.% total metal and the reduced Al2O3 supported catalysts containing 30wt.% total metal are shown in Figs. 4 and 5 . These catalysts were reduced at 773K in H2 for 4h. As mentioned above, the XRD patterns of the calcined and reduced Al2O3 supported catalysts containing 10wt.% total metal were dominated by the support and not shown for brevity. In addition to the diffraction features of the support other diffraction features observed in the reduced catalysts suggest the presence of Ni, NiO, Fe and Fe3O4. The presence of these phases in Ni and Fe supported catalysts have been previously reported [30–34]. For the reduced 0Ni10.0Fe/SiO2 sample only metallic Fe was observed, suggesting complete reduction of Fe2O3 to the metallic state. The TPR profile of this 0Ni10.0Fe/SiO2 sample revealed a small peak at 945K. It appears that the iron oxide giving rise to this small peak was present in trace amounts since it was not observed in the XRD patterns of the sample reduced at 773K. When small amounts of Ni were present, as in the reduced 2.5Ni7.5Fe/SiO2 sample, the Fe3O4 species observed in the calcined sample was still observed in the reduced sample. The presence of Fe3O4 in the reduced 2.5Ni7.5Fe/SiO2 sample suggests that this Fe oxide species was difficult to reduce. Additional peaks at 43.64°, 50.87° and 74.81° were observed in the XRD pattern of 2.5Ni7.5Fe/SiO2. These three peaks were attributed to the presence of a Ni–Fe alloy [35]. Increasing the substitution of Fe with Ni resulted in the shift of these three peaks at 43.64°, 50.87° and 74.81° to higher 2θ values and finally to the 2θ values of metallic Ni. Similar shifts in the peak positions of metallic Ni have been previously observed and attributed to the progressive formation of Ni3Fe alloy [36]. For the 0Ni30.0Fe/Al2O3 sample reduced at 773K in H2, Fig. 5 reveals incomplete reduction of Fe2O3 occurs since Fe3O4 and metallic Fe peaks were observed in the XRD pattern. This observation is consistent with the corresponding TPR profile shown in Fig. 3. Substituting 25% of Fe with Ni, as in the reduced 7.5Ni22.5Fe/Al2O3 sample, also revealed the presence of Fe3O4, again suggesting the incomplete reduction of Fe oxide. In addition to the Fe3O4 peaks three peaks at 43.64°, 50.87° and 74.81° were observed, which were attributed to the formation of a Ni–Fe alloy. Furthermore, these three peaks shift in position and approach the 2θ values of metallic Ni as the substitution of Fe with Ni is increased. These observations were similar to the SiO2 supported Ni–Fe catalysts that were reduced at 773K. For the reduced 30.0Ni0Fe/Al2O3 sample, incomplete reduction of NiO was observed, suggesting the role of the support toward the reducibility of NiO. In the presence of Fe, however, NiO peaks were not observed in the reduced samples. It appears that the reducibility of NiO was more readily achieved in the presence of Fe. The crystallite size values for the most prominent XRD peak of Ni or Ni–Fe alloy or Fe of the metal supported reduced catalysts were determined and tabulated, as in Table 1. As mentioned above the XRD patterns of the 10% Al2O3 supported catalysts were dominated by the support feature and were not amenable for crystallite size determination. Analysis of the remaining catalysts data in Table 1 revealed that the crystallite size values were relatively smaller for the 7.5Ni2.5Fe/SiO2 catalyst though the total metal loading was the same. The crystallite size values for the Al2O3 supported catalysts containing 30% total metal loading, however, increased and then decreased when the Fe content increased. An increase in crystallite size value for the same total metal loading would suggest a decrease in the number of surface metal sites available. Thus, the variation in crystallite size values with change in the Ni and Fe composition for the same total metal loading does not appear to follow a common trend. The amount of H2 chemisorbed for 10% and 30% Al2O3 supported Ni, Fe and Ni–Fe catalysts were also determined from the H2-TPD data and tabulated, as in Table 1. For the SiO2 supported catalysts, the H2-TPD was difficult to obtain. Analysis of the data for both Al2O3 supported 10% and 30% series of catalysts revealed that H2 chemisorptions amount initially increased with an increase in Fe content and then decreased for the pure Fe supported Al2O3 catalysts. The increase in the amount of H2 chemisorbed suggested that a larger number of surface metal sites were available. The supports were tested for the CO2 hydrogenation reaction and negligible CO2 conversion was observed under the operating conditions considered. The supported Ni, Fe and series of Ni–Fe catalysts of varying Ni to Fe ratios were also tested for the CO2 hydrogenation reaction and the results are shown in Figs. 6 and 7 . In Fig. 6 the catalytic activities for CO2 conversion and CH4 yield at 523K are shown as a function of the composition of the SiO2 supported catalysts containing 10% total metal loading. In Fig. 7 the catalytic activities for CO2 conversion and CH4 yield at 523K are shown as a function of the catalyst composition of the Al2O3 supported catalysts containing 10% and 30% total metal loading. Comparing the data of Figs. 6 and 7 revealed that for a 10% total metal loading, the Al2O3 supported catalysts showed a significantly higher CO2 conversion and CH4 yield. The lower conversion and yield for the SiO2 supported catalysts were despite the higher degree of reduction achieved. It appears that: larger metal crystallites were formed on the SiO2 supported catalysts compared to the Al2O3 supported catalysts of the same total metal loading and/or the Al2O3 support assists in increasing the conversion and yield. Thus, the support plays an important role toward the activity of the metal sites during CO2 hydrogenation. In Fig. 7, the CO2 conversion and CH4 yield at 523K are shown as a function of the catalyst composition also for the Al2O3 supported catalysts containing 30% total metal loading. The conversions and yield of this series of catalysts was the highest amongst the three series of catalysts studied. Furthermore, the conversions of the Al2O3 and SiO2 supported Ni catalysts were significantly larger than those observed for the Al2O3 and SiO2 supported Fe catalysts. A more detailed analysis of Figs. 6 and 7 revealed that a maximum in CO2 conversion and CH4 yield were observed for the SiO2 and Al2O3 supported catalysts containing 75% of the total metal loading as Ni and 25% of the total metal loading as Fe. Similar trends were observed at 548K and the results are not shown for brevity. Most of the supported catalysts produced CH4 as the main reaction product. The Fe rich samples, however, produced significant amounts of CO. Furthermore, the conversions and yields for the 7.5Ni2.5Fe/Al2O3 and 22.5Ni7.5Fe/Al2O3 catalysts were enhanced by a factor of about two when compared with the 10.0Ni0Fe/Al2O3 and 30.0Ni0Fe/Al2O3 catalysts. Relatively lower enhancements of conversion and yield were observed for the 7.5Ni2.5Fe/SiO2 catalyst when compared to the 10.0Ni0Fe/SiO2 catalyst. The enhancements of CO2 conversion and CH4 yield were by a factor of 1.3 and 1.2, respectively. Thus, enhancements of conversion and yield were observed for a specific Ni and Fe composition corresponding to a Ni:Fe ratio of 3:1. Furthermore, the support also plays a role in the amount of enhancements. Previous studies have also observed an enhancement of CO2 conversion over Ni–Fe catalysts supported on Al2O3 containing a total metal loading of 25wt.% while studying the CO2 hydrogenation reaction [6]. In that study the maximum CO2 conversion rate was also found for the catalysts containing 75% Ni and 25% Fe. Enhancements of CO conversion and CH4 yield were also observed for the CO hydrogenation to CH4 reaction over Ni–Fe supported catalysts for specific Ni and Fe contents [18]. For the MgAl2O4 supported catalysts with total metal loadings of 2.5 and 10wt.%, the CO conversion increased two and three times, respectively. In this previous study the enhancement appeared to depend on the total metal loading. Furthermore, at high total metal loadings a 50Ni50Fe composition provided a better reaction rate suggesting that the specific Ni and Fe composition in the most active catalyst was a function of total metal loading. However, the present study revealed that the enhancements of CO2 conversion and CH4 yield were about two times for the Al2O3 supported catalysts and was relatively independent of total metal loadings. Furthermore, the highest conversion was achieved at a composition of 75% Ni and 25% Fe for both loadings. In addition to the effect of the total metal loading the present study also revealed that the support plays an important role in determining the conversion and yield and the specific enhancements of conversion and yield. The present study reveals that the composition of the Al2O3 and SiO2 supported catalysts that provide the best conversion and yield corresponds to the composition of a Ni3Fe alloy. Previous studies have also suggested this [18,35]. The presence of other bulk alloys with the composition NiFe and Ni2Fe has also been reported [18]. The presence of Ni–Fe alloys was indeed observed in the XRD patterns of the Al2O3 supported catalysts containing 30wt.% and SiO2 supported Ni–Fe catalysts containing 10wt.% total metal loading. The XRD patterns of the Al2O3 supported Ni–Fe catalysts containing 10wt.% total metal loading were inconclusive due to the dominating support peaks. It is likely that Ni–Fe alloys were also present for this sample considering the similarity of: (i) the UV–vis spectra of the calcined samples, (ii) the TPR profile when compared with the samples containing 30% total metal, and (iii) the catalytic behavior. The progressive shift in the three XRD peaks occurs with the gradual substitution of Fe with Ni until they coincide with the peak position of metallic Ni. The progressive shift in peak positions does not, however, directly correlate with trends in the CO2 conversion of the different catalysts. It has been suggested that for the Ni–Fe supported catalysts the formation of Ni3Fe surface structures occurs and that this may be the reason for enhancements in CO2 conversion and CH4 yield [18]. It is, however, uncertain where such structures are formed and how, if at all, these structures influence the CO2 conversion and CH4 yield of these three series of supported Ni–Fe catalysts. Specifically, the three peaks progressively shift with increasing substitution, whereas the CO2 conversion and CH4 yield goes through a maximum. Thus, it appears that the formation of a suitable Ni–Fe alloy, such as Ni3Fe, resulted in the formation of new active sites. These new active sites gave rise to the enhancements of conversion and yield. Other reasons for the enhanced activity of supported Ni–Fe bimetallic catalysts have been suggested. For example, it was suggested that the reduction of Ni–Fe bimetallic catalyst occurs at a much lower temperature compared to the monometallic Fe catalyst [29,37,38]. Comparing the activity data with the TPR profiles for the SiO2 supported catalysts reveals that much lower reduction temperatures were not achieved for the SiO2 supported Ni–Fe catalysts. In fact for the SiO2 supported catalyst that was reduced at 773K most, if not all, of the supported metal oxides were reduced to the metal. The degree of reduction for the SiO2 supported catalysts, however, does appear to follow the changes in activity. The most active in this series of catalysts, 7.5Ni2.5Fe/SiO2, revealed the highest degree of reduction. The higher degree of reduction would suggest the formation of a larger number of metal sites. The relatively smaller crystallite size value for the 7.5Ni2.5Si/SiO2 catalyst as shown in Table 1 is also consistent with the larger number of surface metal sites. Correlating the data from these characterization studies with the activity it would appear that the enhancement of activity was indeed due to the larger number of active sites formed on the 7.5Ni2.5Fe/SiO2 catalyst. However, the role played by Ni–Fe alloys, if any, in the formation larger number of active sites for the SiO2 supported catalysts still remains unclear. Thus, the enhancements of CO2 conversion and CH4 yield appear to be due to the larger number of metal sites and the presence of a suitable Ni–Fe alloy. The reason for enhancements of conversion and yield for the most active Al2O3 supported Ni–Fe catalyst was more difficult to suggest. This difficulty was due to the smaller degrees of reduction and no definite correlation between the degree of reduction given in Table 1 and enhancements of CO2 conversion and CH4 yield of the Al2O3 supported catalysts shown in Fig. 7. The changes in crystallite size and H2 chemisorption values given in Table 1 also did not correlate with the enhancements of CO2 conversion and CH4 yield. Furthermore, the enhancements of conversion and yield were more for the Al2O3 supported catalysts than the enhancements for the SiO2 supported catalysts. Taking into account the above information it appears that there are multiple reasons associated with the enhancements of conversion and yield for the CO2 hydrogenation reaction when some Ni is substituted with Fe. These reasons include: the creation of additional sites (viz., SiO2 supported catalysts) and formation of a suitable alloy (viz., SiO2 and Al2O3 supported catalysts). To facilitate our understanding of the enhancements in conversion and yield the DRIFT spectra of the Al2O3 and SiO2 supported catalysts were obtained during the CO2 hydrogenation reaction at 523K. Simultaneously collection of the reaction data was also achieved, which revealed an enhancement of CH4 yield for the 7.5Ni2.5Fe/Al2O3 and 22.5Ni7.5Fe/Al2O3 catalyst. The reactivity data are not shown for brevity. For the SiO2 supported catalyst the DRIFT spectra were not informative and were also not included for brevity. The DRIFT spectra for the Al2O3 support and the series of Al2O3 supported catalysts containing 10% total metal loading are shown in Fig. 8 . For the Al2O3 support peaks at 1433 and 1649cm−1 were observed. These peaks were attributed to bicarbonate species on the surface [39]. For the 10.0Ni0Fe/Al2O3 catalysts, two new peaks at 1373 and 1593cm−1 dominate the spectrum as shown in Fig. 8. These two new peaks were due to the presence of formate species [40]. For the 0Ni10.0Fe/Al2O3 catalyst a peak at 1545cm−1 was observed. This peak at 1545cm−1 was due to the presence of carbonate species [40]. For the Al2O3 supported Ni–Fe catalysts containing 10wt.% total metal the formate and carbonate species were present with varying intensities. The spectra of the Ni rich and 5.0Ni5.0Fe/Al2O3 samples were dominated by formate species and the spectra of the Fe rich samples possessed significant amounts of carbonate species. Table 1 suggests that the Fe rich samples, 0Ni10.0Fe/Al2O3 and 2.5Ni7.5Fe/Al2O3, were not completely reduced. It is likely that the Fe oxides present in these samples were responsible for the adsorbed carbonate species. The presence of carbonate species in the DRIFT spectra of the Ni rich and 5.0Ni5.0Fe/Al2O3 samples was not conclusive since the spectra were dominated by the formate bands. The DRIFT spectrum of the 30.0Ni0Fe/Al2O3 catalyst shown in Fig. S4 (in Supplementary information) was also dominated by the formate peaks. The 22.5Ni7.5Fe/Al2O3 and 15.0Ni15.0Fe/Al2O3 catalysts revealed the presence of formate peaks and a weak carbonate peak at about 1540cm−1. Based on the carbonate species observed on the 0Ni10.0Fe/Al2O3 and 2.5Ni7.5Fe/Al2O3 catalysts it would appear that the weak carbonate species observed were due to small amounts of unreduced Fe3O4, which were not detected in the XRD patterns. For the 0Ni30.0Fe/Al2O3 and 7.5Ni22.5Fe/Al2O3 catalysts the spectra were weak and not shown for brevity. The presence of carbonate species under in situ reaction conditions provides an additional reason for enhancements of conversion and yield. The trace amounts of Fe3O4 that might be present on the surface of the reduced catalyst would be a source of supplying adsorbed carbonate species to the Ni site for the CO2 hydrogenation reaction to occur. The surface diffusion of the adsorbed carbonate species formed on the Fe oxide site would be more beneficial than the direct adsorption of CO2 on to the Ni site before the CO2 hydrogenation reaction proceeds. Thus, in addition to the presence of a suitable alloy and the increase of the number of metal sites formed due to the presence of small amounts of Fe, the enhancements of conversion and yield may be due to the presence of unreduced Fe oxide sites that supply adsorbed carbonate species for the CO2 hydrogenation reaction to occur more efficiently. 4 Conclusion Catalysts containing 75% of the total metal as Ni and 25% as Fe supported on Al2O3 of two total metal loadings showed significantly better CO2 conversion and CH4 yield in comparison with the monometallic Ni and Fe supported on Al2O3 catalysts. The enhancements in CO2 conversion and yield were similar for these two total metal loadings on the Al2O3 support. However, the enhancements did not correlate with the amount of H2 chemisorbed. The SiO2 supported Ni–Fe catalysts also showed enhancements, but the enhancements of conversion and yield were lower than those observed for the Al2O3 supported catalysts. For the SiO2 supported Ni–Fe catalysts the enhancements appeared to be due to the additional metal sites formed. The presence of a Ni–Fe alloy was also observed, which may also give rise to the enhancements of conversion and yield. The XRD patterns of the reduced catalysts reveal gradual shifts in the peak positions of metallic Ni with the progressive substitution of one metal with the other. However, these shifts do not correlate with the catalytic activity. The presence of a suitable Ni–Fe alloy, such as Ni3Fe, may be required for the enhancements of conversion and yield. In situ DRIFT spectra obtained during the CO2 hydrogenation reaction revealed the presence of varying amounts of formate and carbonate species for the Al2O3 supported Ni, Fe and Ni–Fe catalysts. The presence of adsorbed carbonate due to unreduced Fe3O4 species on the Al2O3 supported Ni–Fe catalyst may also be a reason for the enhancements of conversion and yield to occur. Thus, the enhancements in conversion and yield of the CO2 hydrogenation reaction over supported Ni–Fe catalysts may be due to the (i) increase in number of metal sites (viz., SiO2 supported catalysts), (ii) formation of a suitable alloy (viz., SiO2 and Al2O3 supported catalysts), and (iii) availability of adsorbed carbonate species on the catalyst surface (viz., Al2O3 supported catalysts) or a combination of the these three factors. coredata.dc:description: Nickel (Ni), iron (Fe) and three series of Ni–Fe bimetallic catalysts supported on alumina and silica were tested for the CO2 hydrogenation reaction at 448–548K. The supported Ni–Fe catalysts containing 75wt.% of the total metal loading as Ni and 25wt.% as Fe showed a significantly better CO2 conversion and higher methane (CH4) yield compared to the Ni and Fe supported catalysts. Furthermore, the enhancements of conversion and yield were higher for the alumina supported catalysts than for the silica supported catalysts. The enhancements appear to be independent of total metal loading. It appears that the enhancements of conversion and yield were due to the formation of a suitable Ni–Fe alloy, and/or increase in the number of metal sites, and/or the availability of adsorbed CO2 species.
coredata.dc:title: Promotional effects in alumina and silica supported bimetallic Ni–Fe catalysts during CO2 hydrogenation
